author: Mohammad Ali
text:
Students and faculty members of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU), along with the residents of Meerut, launched a campaign on Monday saying the local administration should ensure that the critically acclaimed film Aligarh is shown in cinemas.

The film could not be screened in Aligarh, reportedly due to the anti-film stance taken by some fringe groups who believed that the film “defamed” the city.

The campaign, #AligarhinAligarh, is led by a group of young women students of AMU. The campaign — which first started online — has now been taken to the streets. The group behind it has managed to get signatures of hundreds of residents as well.

A Ph.D. scholar of AMU, Fizza Husain, who is a member of the campaign group, explained the rationale behind #AligarhinAligarh.

“I felt the ban was unnecessary because all of us have the right to watch what we want. At no point did I feel that the movie has defamed the city. It is a story of the struggle of Professor Siras, which needs to be told and watched,” Mr. Husain said.
title: AMU students launch campaign for Aligarh
